column4: Hey guy's, is it ok to ask Ubuntu related questions here or should i pop over to the beginner chat?

I installed Ubuntu 11.04 to a 8GB Flash drive, i used 4GB(the max) for reserved space? so that i could have room to treat it like a side OS, well after updates and nothing else i am getting "Not enough Space" warnings
There wasn't an option to go larger than 4028MB
maybe you need to clean package cache (/var/cache/apt/archives/) via sudo apt-get clean
but have a look how much space you have left after cleaning that, guess not much then :P
persistent file size for storing changes sounds confusing, more like reserved space as separate partition?
as this is optional i guess it's just that, you have 8gig and the option says keep 4g for something else?
hmm so you have enough space there? what does df -h say?
- it breaks it down further, /dev/loop0 size is 665M, and 100%, i have alto of info here if you wanted soemthing specific
you can put that in http://paste.ubuntu.com
so i guess that program you used just reserved 4GB on the stick, have a look at the partitions there
Is that not what i want? i notice it's using 80%, and i did select for it to use the maximum partition space
at the moment it looks like it's just unused space, have a look at it with gparted or fdisk/cfdisk
it does not show up in Gparted
ok it says Size: 7.47GiB | Used 4.70GiB (63%) | Unused 2.77 GiB (37%) - that is a tone of usage for only having installed recommended updates.

Is there a more proper way to install Ubuntu 11.04 to a USB and make it act as a HDD? That utility is causing mroe problems than anything, this is just disk usage, i haven't even started about the error's i keep recieveing
Ubuntu also has it's own tool similar to the one you used, you may want to reduce the reserved space for storing changes then, 4G for system is not that much
with that size you need to clean up often, remove old kernels etc. or remove software you won't use
is it possible for me to 1:1 with you? I would feel much better about sharing my uses and what i wish to occomplish using linux 1:1
